awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research:  Police Technology and Urban Governance
awd_abstract_narration:
This dissertation research project explores the role of technology in urban policing. Anthropology doctoral student,  Elliott Liu, under the supervision of Dr. Jeff Maskovsky at the City University of New York Graduate Center, will study the arrangement of technical and governmental relationships through which knowledge about disorder, crime, space, place and other social characteristics are produced. Today technology not only informs police patrol and investigative activities, but also broader discussions of the mission, effectiveness, and legitimacy of police institutions and city governments. Yet not enough is known about the use of the spatial, demographic and statistical knowledge produced by police departments, the circulation and effects of this knowledge in other governing institutions, and how this has changed over time. 

The research will be undertaken in New York city. The researcher will combine archival and ethnographic methods in his investigation. He will undertake participant observation at public meetings and ride-alongs with officers in four precincts currently targeted for city intervention. He also will conduct interviews and focus groups with former police department officers and civilian employees about past technology use. Finally, he will evaluate these data against the backdrop of archival research tracing the development of police technologies from the automation of data processing in the 1950s to the analytics-driven policing model developing currently. Findings from this research will broaden insights into the role of technology in shaping police practices and public perception of police, safety, and urban governance. Conclusions will advance anthropological theory by extending work on actor-network theory and techno-politics to the study of urban governance and spatial management.

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to understand the role technocratic policing plays in contemporary urban governance, by exploring how crime “hot spots” are constructed, how they are mobilized by law enforcement and community actors, and how they come into play in broader public discourse about crime and policing in contemporary cities. The project entailed twelve months of ethnographic and archival research with the New York Police Department. The co-PI conducted fieldwork at semi-public meetings at police precincts, NYPD headquarters, and professional conferences of police administrators and unionists; interviewed retired police administrators and civilian analysts; and surveyed professional publications and internal studies carried out at the NYPD since the 1950s.

 

Findings indicate that technocratic policing requires a range of technological and social conditions in order to achieve effectiveness and legitimacy. For example, crime maps rely on both physical paperwork systems and software platforms to compile and manipulate information in such a way that analysts can assume they transparently reflect social reality. Their success also requires constituencies—within law enforcement agencies and in the communities they police—to accept the procedures used to generate data, and the policies formulated through analyzing and interpreting it. A conjuncture of these conditions, findings show, is relatively rare: the history of the NYPD in the post-war period is in large part a string of partially-realized attempts to implement technocratic policing regimes in response to successive political crises.

 

Despite their complexities, however, technocratic practices are attractive in the post-Civil Rights period precisely because they encourage law enforcement and community actors to understand policing as a colorblind enterprise, even as the ways police collect and act upon data continue to be shaped by racially unequal practices and assumptions. Criticism of police, by extension, tends not only to draw into question specific law enforcement practices, but also the rationality of policing itself and the terms in which racial bias is defined. This project suggests that urban governance rests on a shifting technical and social foundation whose stability is never assured, even as it defines the terms of debate over police practice. Findings will contribute to discussions in urban anthropology and Americanist anthropology about the ways putatively colorblind urban governance has been achieved in the neoliberal era, and the tensions and instabilities to which the project has given rise.
